unit_title: Vector Algebra: Mathematical Operations with Vectors
subject: Physics/Mathematics
expanded_description: Comprehensive study of vector mathematics including vector representation, operations (addition, subtraction, scalar multiplication), dot product, cross product, and applications in physics problems involving forces, displacement, and other vector quantities.

core_concept.principle: Vectors are mathematical objects with both magnitude and direction that follow specific algebraic rules for addition, subtraction, and multiplication, enabling precise description of physical quantities like force, velocity, and displacement in multiple dimensions.
core_concept.explanation: Vector algebra provides the mathematical foundation for analyzing multi-dimensional systems, with operations like dot product giving scalar results (work, energy) and cross product giving vector results (torque, angular momentum), following distinct mathematical properties.

image.caption: Vector operations: triangle law for addition, projection for dot product, and right-hand rule for cross product, demonstrating the geometric interpretation of vector algebra.

sections.introduction: Vectors provide the mathematical language for describing quantities with both magnitude and direction, forming the essential framework for analyzing physical systems in two and three dimensions.

image.alt: 3D coordinate system showing vector components and unit vectors
image.caption: Vector representation in 3D space: components along x, y, z axes with unit vectors î, ĵ, k̂

key_concept.definition: A vector is a mathematical object characterized by magnitude (length) and direction, represented as $\vec{A} = A_x\hat{i} + A_y\hat{j} + A_z\hat{k}$ in component form, with magnitude $|\vec{A}| = \sqrt{A_x^2 + A_y^2 + A_z^2}$ and direction given by unit vector $\hat{A} = \frac{\vec{A}}{|\vec{A}|}$.
key_concept.context: This representation enables precise mathematical manipulation of directional quantities like force, velocity, and displacement in physics and engineering applications.

principles.statement: Two vectors are equal if they have same magnitude and direction, and parallel if one is scalar multiple of the other: $\vec{A} \parallel \vec{B} \iff \vec{A} = k\vec{B}$ for some scalar k
principles.application: This enables vector comparison, force equilibrium analysis, and direction determination in physics problems
principles.example: Vectors $2\hat{i} + 3\hat{j}$ and $4\hat{i} + 6\hat{j}$ are parallel since second vector = 2 × first vector
principles.analogy: Like similar triangles - parallel vectors maintain same direction but can have different magnitudes

principles.statement: A unit vector has magnitude 1 and indicates pure direction, with any vector expressible as $\vec{A} = |\vec{A}|\hat{A}$, separating magnitude and direction components
principles.application: This simplifies direction specification, enables coordinate system definition, and facilitates vector decomposition
principles.example: For $\vec{v} = 3\hat{i} + 4\hat{j}$, magnitude = 5, unit vector = $0.6\hat{i} + 0.8\hat{j}$ representing direction only
principles.analogy: Like pure numbers vs measured quantities - unit vectors provide direction without magnitude

sections.introduction: Vector addition follows geometric rules that account for both magnitude and direction, with the parallelogram law and triangle law providing intuitive geometric interpretations of the algebraic operations.

image.alt: Multiple vectors being added using triangle method showing head-to-tail arrangement
image.caption: Vector addition: head-to-tail arrangement forms path from start to finish, resultant closes the triangle

key_concept.definition: Vector addition is commutative ($\vec{A} + \vec{B} = \vec{B} + \vec{A}$) and associative ($\vec{A} + (\vec{B} + \vec{C}) = (\vec{A} + \vec{B}) + \vec{C}$), performed component-wise: $\vec{A} + \vec{B} = (A_x+B_x)\hat{i} + (A_y+B_y)\hat{j} + (A_z+B_z)\hat{k}$, while subtraction is defined as $\vec{A} - \vec{B} = \vec{A} + (-\vec{B})$.
key_concept.context: These operations enable the composition of multiple vector quantities, essential for analyzing net forces, resultant velocities, and combined displacements in physical systems.

image.alt: Diagrams showing commutative and associative properties of vector addition
image.caption: Vector addition properties: A+B = B+A (commutative), (A+B)+C = A+(B+C) (associative)

sections.introduction: Scalar multiplication changes vector magnitude while preserving or reversing direction, while the dot product provides a scalar measure of vector alignment and enables projection calculations essential for work and energy computations.

image.alt: Diagram showing scalar multiplication effects and dot product projection
image.caption: Scalar multiplication scales vector; dot product measures alignment and enables projection

key_concept.definition: Scalar multiplication: $k\vec{A} = kA_x\hat{i} + kA_y\hat{j} + kA_z\hat{k}$ scales magnitude by |k| and reverses direction if k < 0. Dot product: $\vec{A} \cdot \vec{B} = |\vec{A}||\vec{B}|\cos\theta = A_xB_x + A_yB_y + A_zB_z$ measures parallel component product.
key_concept.context: These operations enable vector scaling, projection calculations, work computations ($W = \vec{F} \cdot \vec{d}$), and angle determination between vectors in physical applications.

image.alt: Vectors with angle between them showing projection concept
image.caption: Dot product geometry: A·B = |A||B|cosθ represents projection of one vector onto another

principles.statement: The dot product is commutative ($\vec{A} \cdot \vec{B} = \vec{B} \cdot \vec{A}$), distributive ($\vec{A} \cdot (\vec{B} + \vec{C}) = \vec{A} \cdot \vec{B} + \vec{A} \cdot \vec{C}$), and related to magnitude ($\vec{A} \cdot \vec{A} = |\vec{A}|^2$), with zero dot product indicating perpendicular vectors
principles.application: These properties simplify calculations, enable perpendicularity testing, and provide geometric interpretations of vector relationships
principles.example: For perpendicular vectors $\hat{i} \cdot \hat{j} = 0$, while $\hat{i} \cdot \hat{i} = 1$ shows unit magnitude
principles.analogy: Like measuring alignment - maximum when parallel, zero when perpendicular, negative when opposed

image.alt: Diagrams showing dot product for parallel, perpendicular, and opposite vectors
image.caption: Dot product values: maximum (positive) when parallel, zero when perpendicular, negative when opposed

principles.statement: The projection of $\vec{A}$ onto $\vec{B}$ gives the component of $\vec{A}$ parallel to $\vec{B}$, with magnitude $|\vec{A}|\cos\theta$ representing the effective component in the $\vec{B}$ direction
principles.application: This enables force decomposition, work calculations, and component analysis in specific directions
principles.example: Work done by force $\vec{F}$ through displacement $\vec{d}$ is $W = \vec{F} \cdot \vec{d} = |\vec{F}||\vec{d}|\cos\theta$, depending only on parallel component
principles.analogy: Like shadow length - projection shows how much of one vector 'casts shadow' on another

image.alt: Vector projection shown as shadow cast perpendicular to direction
image.caption: Projection analogy: like shadow of vector A falling onto direction of vector B

sections.introduction: The cross product generates a vector perpendicular to both input vectors, with magnitude equal to the area of the parallelogram they span, providing the mathematical basis for torque, angular momentum, and rotational quantities.

image.alt: Right-hand rule demonstration for cross product with perpendicular result
image.caption: Cross product: A×B perpendicular to both A and B, direction given by right-hand rule

key_concept.definition: Cross product: $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = |\vec{A}||\vec{B}|\sin\theta\hat{n}$, where $\hat{n}$ is unit vector perpendicular to both following right-hand rule. Component form: $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (A_yB_z - A_zB_y)\hat{i} + (A_zB_x - A_xB_z)\hat{j} + (A_xB_y - A_yB_x)\hat{k}$.
key_concept.context: This vector product describes rotational effects, with applications in torque ($\vec{\tau} = \vec{r} \times \vec{F}$), magnetic force ($\vec{F} = q\vec{v} \times \vec{B}$), and area calculations in physics and engineering.

image.alt: Geometric interpretation of cross product with parallelogram area
image.caption: Cross product magnitude equals parallelogram area; direction follows right-hand rule perpendicular to plane

summary: Vector algebra provides mathematical operations for quantities with both magnitude and direction. Vectors are represented as $\vec{A} = A_x\hat{i} + A_y\hat{j} + A_z\hat{k}$ with magnitude $|\vec{A}| = \sqrt{A_x^2 + A_y^2 + A_z^2}$. Vector addition is commutative and associative, performed component-wise. Scalar multiplication scales vector magnitude by factor k, reversing direction if k < 0. Dot product $\vec{A} \cdot \vec{B} = A_xB_x + A_yB_y + A_zB_z = |\vec{A}||\vec{B}|\cos\theta$ gives scalar result measuring parallel components, used for work calculations ($W = \vec{F} \cdot \vec{d}$), angle determination, and testing perpendicularity (dot product = 0). Cross product $\vec{A} \times \vec{B}$ gives vector perpendicular to both inputs with magnitude $|\vec{A}||\vec{B}|\sin\theta$ equal to parallelogram area, following right-hand rule for direction, used for torque ($\vec{\tau} = \vec{r} \times \vec{F}$) and rotational quantities. Key properties: dot product is commutative, cross product is anti-commutative ($\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = -\vec{B} \times \vec{A}$); both operations are distributive over addition. Vector projection: $\text{proj}_{\vec{B}}\vec{A} = \frac{\vec{A} \cdot \vec{B}}{|\vec{B}|^2}\vec{B}$ gives component of A parallel to B.
